awd_titl_txt: Dried Blood Spot Biomarker Development for Addressing Evolutionary and Biocultural Questions
awd_abstract_narration:
Biomarkers are objective measures of biological processes that help to describe an individual's physiological condition. In this project, the investigators will develop and validate six minimally-invasive dried blood spot biomarkers with relevance to studies of modern human populations, adaptation, and life history. Despite significant progress on the development and application of biomarkers for use in the social and behavioral sciences, there is a need to address critical issues and limitations, and to systematically develop and optimize biomarkers. The biomarkers developed in this project will support the investigation of important theoretical questions in biological anthropology and human biology about stress, aging, and immune function, and will set the standard for future dried blood spot assay development. A biobank of quality control samples will be created and shared with other laboratories that wish to develop their own biomarkers, so that results will be comparable across studies and laboratories. The project will also provide educational training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students. 

This research will develop and validate six dried blood spot immunoassay biomarkers in order to expand the methodological toolkit in biological anthropology for application to four topics of major interest to the field: 1) autoimmune disease (myeloperoxidase [pANCA], an indicator of inflammatory bowel disease, and anti-thyroid peroxidase antibody [TPOAb], a marker of autoimmune thyroid disorders); 2) regulation of systemic inflammation (the anti-inflammatory cytokine interleukin-10 [IL-10]); 3) bone turnover (carboxylated osteocalcin [cOC], a marker of bone formation, and tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase 5b [TRACP5b], a marker of bone resorption); and, 4) stress-related aging (the protein marker Klotho). The project team will develop these assays using matched dried blood spot and venipuncture-obtained whole blood samples from 200 adults from the Eugene, Oregon area. The systematic process of evaluation, modification, and validation to be used in this study is the most rigorous strategy to develop DBS biomarkers and the resulting publications will serve as benchmarks for further biomarker validation efforts. The research will result in: 1) six technical publications with assay validations and protocols; 2) detailed written assay protocols (in multiple languages) and video instructions available in a publicly available repository; 3) biobank materials for cross-laboratory harmonization available upon request to other labs; 4) technical training of a graduate student; 5) undergraduate research opportunities for 12 undergraduates, including those from underrepresented populations; and 6) a session at a national conference on the state of the science with respect to dried blood spots.

por.por_cntn:
We successfully developed lab-based tests to measure the levels of three biomarkers in dried blood spots (DBS) that are of interest to biological anthropologists, as well as scientists in other population sciences such as epidemiology. Dried blood spots are the sample type of choice for anthropologists working with populations in remote areas (whether in the US or internationally), as these samples are collected by pricking a finger with a lancet and then collecting the resulting drops of blood on a special filter card. Once the blood has dried, these cards can generally be shipped via regular mail or transported without ice back to a laboratory for processing. This contrasts with the processing, storage, and shipping requirements of whole blood collected via venipuncture.

We were particularly interested in developing tests to measure three proteins in DBS samples: TRACP-5b, which reflects bone breakdown; osteocalcin, which reflects bone formation; and, thyroid peroxidase autoantibodies, which are produced in large amounts in individuals with thyroid autoimmune diseases.

We chose to measure the two bone-related proteins from DBS to obtain insights into the dynamics of bone turnover (breakdown and formation) in non-Western populations like the Shuar of Ecuador and Tsimane of Brazil who are exposed to different ecological factors and life stresses than typical urbanized populations from wealthy nations. Our expectation is that we will likely see different patterns of bone turnover in these populations because of variation in factors known to influence bone turnover, like hormonal status, physical activity level, genetics, and reproductive patterns. This will allow a more complete understanding of the basic biology of bone, which will inform interventions and treatments in wealthy nations such as the US. A major outcome of the project is that we have expanded the biological anthropology toolkit to add two bone markers that can be measured using a minimally invasive approach.

The ability to measure levels of the marker of thyroid autoimmune disorders, namely TPO-Ab, in DBS will allow anthropologists and other population scientists to directly test one of the most widely popularized hypotheses, the Old Friends Hypothesis. This hypothesis proposes that increased hygiene, urbanization, and lifestyle changes over the past several decades have reduced our exposure to macroparasites and microbes that we co-evolved with, thereby removing vital stimuli for immune development and leading to immune dysregulation and increased susceptibility to autoimmune and allergic diseases. However, few studies have directly tested this hypothesis, and most of these were conducted in population samples from wealthy nations. As a result, we have an incomplete understanding of the human immune system. By having the ability to measure a marker of autoimmune disorders in DBS, we can directly assess if traditionally living populations, who are exposed to greater parasite and pathogen loads such as those encountered during most of our evolutionary history, have lower levels of autoimmune proteins, like TPO-Ab, as we would expect if the Old Friends Hypothesis is correct. The availability of the TPO-Ab test from samples collected using minimally invasive means expands the biological anthropology toolkit and will position the field to refine our understanding of human ecological immunology.

All the tests we have developed can be performed in biological anthropology laboratories with standard, inexpensive equipment, and we are sharing how to perform these tests freely with all people who wish to run them by posting our protocols on freely accessible websites in addition to publishing how we developed and/or validated these tests in peer-reviewed scientific journals. In addition, based on our experience developing tests for these protein markers in DBS, as well as other proteins that we could not successfully measure in DBS, we have developed guidelines for how other researchers should go about developing tests for protein biomarkers in DBS, including what proteins are likely to be unmeasurable and how to determine this quickly before too much time and money are invested. Furthermore, we describe issues and challenges related to the development of in-house (non-kit-based) immunoassays for use with dried blood spots. This information and these guidelines were presented to experts in the field and students during an invited session (Minimally Invasive Biomarkers in Human Population Biology Research: State of the Science and Future Directions) at the annual meeting of the American Association of Physical Anthropologists in Cleveland, OH in March 2019. Guidelines will be published shortly in the peer-reviewed literature and will be available in extended form on freely accessible websites.
